Berkshire's fourth and fifth highest holdings are famous Buffett buys. Coca-Cola (KO), which Berkshire bought in 1988, represents 8.51% of the portfolio while American Express (AXP), an equity Buffett began buying in the 1960s, is 7.49% of Berkshire's portfolio value. Buffett bought Coca-Cola and Freddie Mac in 1988, telling investors they'd ideally hold them long term. \"We expect to hold these securities for a long time,\" Buffett wrote to shareholders in 1988. \"In fact, when we own portions of outstanding businesses with outstanding managements, our favorite holding period is forever.\" Above Yahoo Finance's Josh Schafer breaks down Berkshire's top holdings. Zacks.com offers in-depth financial research with over 30years of proven results."}, {"date": "20230310110508", "headline": "SXSW 2023: Austin becomes the global center for AI & deep tech", "summary": "There\u2019s something in the air in Austin, Texas, and it\u2019s not the sound of fans cheering on the Longhorns, the twang of a country guitar, or the smell of Texas BBQ. It\u2019s South by Southwest, an annual celebration that\u2019s billed as both a conference and a festival, or somewhere in the middle, but as organizers and veterans will tell you, \u2018you just have to be there.\u2019 It\u2019s a mashup of film, music, tech, and culture. A place where you can watch Ironman lecture a crowd on cyber-security, receive healthcare advice from the Jonas Brothers, and watch a movie premiere in virtual reality, all in one afternoon. But why is this happening? And who\u2019s going? Well, everyone- fans, entrepreneurs, thrill seekers, investors, and they\u2019re all going for the same reason- they\u2019re looking for the next big thing. For the first time in a long time, the tech sector is experiencing a transformation. You\u2019ve read about it in the news, heard about it in the break room, and you\u2019ve seen it with your own eyes on social media. I\u2019m talking about AI and what some are calling \u201cdeep tech\u201d \u2013 those scientific advancements which include innovations in areas like virtual reality and robotics. Between star studded conversations and out-of-this-world exhibits, SXSW will give us a sneak peak into the future and how these new technologies will change our economy and our world, from the way we work, to the way we play. We\u2019ll be speaking to the top thinkers and up and coming entrepreneurs about what all of this means for both businesses and consumers, because we\u2019re on the edge of a brand new era in modern technology, and SXSW\u00a0is the main stage. Over the past few years, there\u2019s been a shift in how we think about the tech industry and the emergence of a new capital city for American business. Tesla (TSLA), Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOGL), Oracle (ORCL)\u2014 why are the world\u2019s most valuable companies all moving to Austin, Texas? Could it be the weather? The taxes? The food? Or maybe it\u2019s the vibe? YF explains", "summary": "TikTok is the hottest social network around, but it\u2019s also got plenty of detractors ranging from lawmakers to the U.S. military. And with a potential ban on the horizon, you might be wondering if you should just kick your TikTok habit now rather than going cold turkey later. But doing that will require more than just deleting the app from your phone. If you really want to give up TikTok, you\u2019ll have to delete your account as well. Thankfully, it\u2019s a relatively painless process, though the platform, like other social media companies, will certainly try to get you to stick around. To finally kick your TikTok habit, you\u2019ll first want to go to your profile page by tapping the Profile button in the bottom right corner of the home screen. Select the options menu, by pressing the hamburger button in the top right of the screen, and tap Settings and Privacy in the pop-up window. Next press Account, then select Deactivate or Delete Account, and pick Delete account permanently. The 92-page decision issued by the U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals largely affirmed the findings of a lower-court judge who presided over a 2021 trial that revolved around an antitrust lawsuit filed by Epic Games, the maker of the popular Fortnite video game.
